Topic: Medicine
Subtopic: Anatomy
Question: The facial artery terminates in the anastomosis with
Choices:
  A: Opposite side of the facial artery
  B: Transverse facial artery
  C: Anastomosis with Infra orbital artery
  D: Branch of the ophthalmic artery
Reflection:
You previously answered this question incorrectly.
Then you reflected on the problem, your solution, and the correct answer.
Use your self-reflection (below) to help you answer this question.
Any information that you are not allowed to see will be marked [REDACTED].
Solution:
The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery that supplies blood to the face.
It terminates in the anastomosis with the infraorbital artery, which is a branch of the ophthalmic artery.
The infraorbital artery supplies blood to the lower eyelid, the lacrimal gland, and the nasal cavity.
It anastomoses with the facial artery to form a ring of blood vessels around the eye.

Action: Answer("D")

After reflecting on the problem and the correct answer, I realized that my mistake was due to a misunderstanding of the anastomosis between the facial artery and the infraorbital artery.
I incorrectly assumed that the facial artery anastomosed with the transverse facial artery (option B), not realizing that the transverse facial artery is actually a branch of the facial artery.
Additionally, I misunderstood the location of the anastomosis, thinking it was closer to the eye than it actually is.
I now understand that the facial artery terminates in the anastomosis with the infraorbital artery, which supplies blood to the lower eyelid, the lacrimal gland, and the nasal cavity.
I will be more careful in my analysis of anastomoses in the future.
